posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hail, ECBers!

This was one of the most difficult builds to do. Boddyknock was a very ingenious character who spent his time researching things, and yet instead of making him a Wizard, Bioware made him a Sorcerer. For a while, I struggled with the idea of making him a double-arcane caster, with 9th level spells on both Wizard and Sorcerer, and then Pally levels for Divine Shield and Save boosts, but it just didn't feel right. It was only when I abandoned the idea of making him a Sorcerer that I built something for him that was satisfying enough. He's essentially a mage, but one who's intelligent enough to understand he needs to learn some defensive combat techniques to help him stay alive, hence Fighter levels, but also quite an engineer who is very interested in little trinkets and magical devices of all sources, hence Rogue levels for Trap skills and UMD. He focuses on two schools, one to damage his foes and the other one to control their minds. He's not made for PvP, so Enchantment is a very good choice. He can cast a high DC Great Thunderclap, which is an often overlooked but very useful spell. He can also use Tenser's Transformation for +17 AB and two extra attacks per round when he's too lazy to cast spells. The best part is that while items don't merge on Tenser's, Epic Mage Armor does, and so does the cast spell of Haste, so he should have a high AC when shifted. Other than that, he has to stick to wearing an Elven Chain Shirt (no spell failure), and on WoG, which is where he is supposed to be played, Shield bracers (give Shield-type AC). On any other a non-arcane failure shield will do the trick. If not, he can have a shield equipped and cast only stilled versions of the spells, as with his settings, he has enough spellbook management for this. This build is the exact same level distribution as GDL's War Wizard (and a couple of others), but has a very different approach, as it doesn't get Auto-still feats and focuses in two schools of magic.

I was very pleased with the result once I abandoned the Sorcerer idea, hope you like him as well: Boddyknock Glinckle, everyone!

posts.author: MrZork
posts.content:
Earlier this year, I started playing a similar gnome wizard/rogue/fighter build through the Saleron's Gambit module and then into Caereena, with a stopover in Eldirin's RDG9 for some leveling. I must admit that I was originally thinking along the lines of Grizzled Dwarflord's War Wizard build, though I made a some different choices with level order and feats. (I wasn't looking for an armored mage and it seems that many PWs have nerfed casting in expertise mode, though that limitation doesn't apply in the OC wherefrom Boddyknock hails.)

Anyway, I wouldn't have thought of the build I was playing as similar to Boddyknock, but I can see how the sorcerer-to-wizard switch allows him to be a much more playable character. Nice work.

A question that comes to mind is the relative value of listen versus spot for wizards (and offensive casters generally, I suppose). I am a fan of the X-ray vision aspect of the listen skill (and gnomes get a head start with it). But, I thought that wizards might benefit more from spot for all of the offensive spells that require line-of-sight for targeting. Does a stealthed enemy detected via listen become a valid target for spells like Magic Missile? Just curious. Of course, an advantage of listen is that an invisible enemy might still be heard (particularly those clunky plate + tower shield types) and then blasted by an AoE spell that can target the terrain...

If a target is detected by Listen, when you have a direct line of sight to it, it's the same as if it had been spotted, the difference is that when you don't see that target directly, you see it as if it was invisible, like when there is a wall between you and the target.
